results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on using webcam-based eye tracking to model attention in neurotypical and neurodivergent learners. (e.g., 'By conducting the study in an ecologically valid, online setting, we gathered data that more accurately reflects real-world learning environments...')
Sections 2.2-2.5 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including participant recruitment, the WebGazer setup, the study procedure, and feature engineering.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.

The document mentions a repository where supplementary material can be found, but does not explicitly state that the raw data is available due to privacy concerns. (e.g., 'Additional information about the specific features used, as well as further details about the study, can be found in the online repository...')
The document describes the variables and preprocessing steps, such as standardization and feature engineering (Section 2.4, 3.1).

Data collection methods are fully described, including the use of Prolific for recruitment (Section 2.1), WebGazer for eye tracking (Section 2.2), and the online reading task with thought probes (Section 2.3).
The document states that the code is available in an open repository (GitHub). (e.g., 'https://github.com/HumanCenteredAI/One-size-does-not-fit-all-supplementary- material.git')
The code is shared, so justification for not sharing is not applicable.

The document states that the repository contains code for data preparation. (e.g., 'Additional information about the specific features used, as well as further details about the study, can be found in the online repository...')
Statistical tests (e.g., k-fold cross-validation), models (Random Forest, SVM, XGBoost), and assumptions (e.g., standardization) are clearly described (Section 3.1).
Effect sizes (Kappa, AUROC) are reported and used for model evaluation (Section 3.1, 3.2, Table 2, Table 3, Table 5, Table 6).
The study is primarily quantitative, with limited subjective context or interpretation.
The study is primarily quantitative, with limited data coding or analysis described.
The results are clearly presented in tables (Table 2, Table 3, Table 5, Table 6) and discussed throughout Section 3 and 4.
Limitations, such as reliance on self-reported diagnoses and webcam-based eye tracking limitations, are discussed in Section 5.3.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on the Open Science Foundation or any other platform.
